Summary: The proposal seeks to improve distributed deep learning scalability by developing a unified infrastructure that combines adaptive communication protocols and hardware-aware scheduling. It targets communication efficiency and hardware utilization, focusing on large-scale models (>1B parameters) and heterogeneous clusters. The method includes an adaptive communication layer, a hardware-aware scheduler, and a unified software stack. The experiment plan covers benchmarks, validation, scaling tests, real-world deployment, and ablation studies.
Strengths: Clear problem statement with relevant literature citations.
Ambitious hypothesis targeting multiplicative gains in efficiency.
Detailed proposed method with three distinct components.
Comprehensive experiment plan, including ablation studies and real-world deployment.
Weaknesses: Feasibility of RL-based scheduling in dynamic environments lacks empirical support.
Real-world deployment plan lacks concrete metrics or success criteria.
No discussion of how the system handles partial failures or degraded performance modes.
Questions: What empirical evidence supports the feasibility of RL-based scheduling in production environments?
What specific KPIs will be used to evaluate success in the real-world deployment?
How will the system maintain performance during partial hardware failures or network partitions?
Limitations: Potential complexity in integrating RL-based scheduling with dynamic cluster states.
Overhead of real-time network telemetry may offset gains in communication efficiency.
Scalability limits under extreme heterogeneity or dynamic workloads.
